pros: Historically has provided job security for employees, competitive, pay and benefits
cons: Some depts are staffed very lean so at times workload can be very high

review_title: Your experience here will depend on what you look like. Management needs serious help.
pros: Employee benefits - employee-student program: if accepted, will fully finance full-time employee's tuition (minus taxes) for certain master's or PhD programs - great health insurance and health options for full-time employees - decent vacation and sick time (but can be difficult to use if you have an unpleasant manager) - walking outdoor space for breaks - Kind managers and coworkers DO exist here but are usually the ones retiring or leaving due to common healthcare administration errors (chaotic environment, overworked, under-appreciated, little changes permitted to increase employee quality of life)
cons: Inconsistent, under-developed management practices - Employees experience exploitative, emotionally abusive behavior among doctoral professionals in management positions - Some managers can be kind (Holiday gatherings, annual department events) and some range from impatient to cold to hostile. Little accountability for management. Lower than avg. pay for majority of positions. Little diversity in board of visitors, management and positions of decision-making but school takes pride in student population's diversity. Cares very much about image. Growth opportunities depend on your manager. Majority of Human Resources personnel have historically spoken to employees with different tones based on who they believe the employee to be. Expect to be under-trained, slim annual raise (if any), under-appreciated, and asked to do 3 people's jobs or stay late/exploitative labor. Anxiety-inducing environments exist in most areas here (laboratories, clinical and administrative) EVMS has since made another parking garage but while I was employed, parking could be inconvenient (parking in desolate parking lot across Brambleton Ave., only accessible to campus via over-the-road bridge, or find street parking @ water-level/flooding risks).

pros: I enjoyed working with the students.
cons: There was little room or support for advancement.

review_title: EVMS is a good place to work medical wise but not the Finance Department
pros: EVMS as a school has a great culture and benefits.
cons: Representation in your other offices matter too. Having 2 incredibly prejudice people who are irreplaceable working in Payroll made way for an incredibly hostile work environment. Management refused to take responsibility for their actions. They were extremely unprofessional. One of which on a daily basis had a bad attitude and called people names under her breath but loud enough to be heard. Management encouraged a workaholic lifestyle and were not understanding of circumstances including health issues or having small children. Only take the Payroll Assistant position if you are okay with being manipulated, abused, and unappreciated. This job is clerical at best and adds no real value to a Payroll career. There is a reason they had no one for this role for 5 months and have cycled through 8 people in 10 years who all either quit or transferred. They are not good at training and communicating.

pros: PTO easy to use. Dental and vision insurance is a good value.
cons: Amount of administrative work placed on clinical staff. Parking is very far away.

Also makes it difficult for career growth due to favoritism. Not a lot of reassurance from leadership when it comes to potential merger talks. A merger might be for the best.

pros: My particular department is supportive up and down the chain from from desk staff to doctors. The general feeling in my department is that the support and understanding of the job do not travel any higher. It is a nice area to live in. For full time employees, the copay is waived for office visits within the EVMS network. Due to the affilitation with the medical school, medical expertise is very good for patients.
cons: Pay is lower than other organizations for the same job in the region. A feeling of disconnect between upper management and medical sites. Perceived lack of interest by upper management. No benefits offered for taking classes/continuing education within the medical school for full time employees. Some of the HR policies are antiquated (examples: must work 40 hours a week to be full time, anything less is part time without benefits. Many organizations consider full time to be 32 or 36 hours. Accrued vacation time is not paid out when employee leaves on good terms).

pros: Learn a lot about healthcare field
cons: Not enough shifts to work when part time

review_title: Relaxed, but not opportunity for growth
pros: Flexible Hours, relaxed atmosphere, friendly coworkers
cons: Limited opportunity for growth within the school

review_title: Program Coordinator - Graduate Program in Public Health
pros:
Providing support for students trying to make a positive impact was inspiring and rewarding.
Attending graduate level courses and professional development seminars provided many educational opportunities.
cons: EVMS as a whole, and the School of Health Sciences specifically, is a viper pit of narcissists. The leadership are completely self-serving and unethical, and do not have the best interests of the students, the instructors, or the community as a whole, in mind at all. The leadership operate with the goal of self-promotion only, at the expense of many hard-working staff, instructors, and students. They have even made decisions that knowingly jeopardize the health and safety of their staff, when it served for their own promotion.

review_title: An organization that has many hidden agendas.  Not a team-centered environment.
pros:
Autonomous work environment.
Interesting material.
Frequent continuing education workshops and courses.
Many restaurants available within walking distance.
cons:
Many negatives.  Job workloads are minimal.  Days move slowly.  One often has to "keep busy".
Lack of team work.  Often a hostile workplace.  A lot of power struggles that cause issues.
Rules and guidelines change without notice so that employees are frequently caught in negative conundrums.
Room for advancement is limited.  Supervisors do not encourage growth and development.
The work could be much more challenging.
There is a lot of wasted talent due to the power issues in the company.
For an academic environment, it was stifling across the board.

job_title: Clinical Research Assistant in Norfolk, VA
pros: I am not micromanaged, am trusted like an adult. This means if I have a doctor's appt or something, I am never questioned as I'm leaving or when I come back, on where I've been.  After 90 days, automatically received 10 days worth of vacation time, and about 7 days worth of sick leave that re-accumulates every pay period. My boss is the best, my department is great. Everyone likes each other, we all get along, we all treat each other with respect and just expect that everyone's doing their job.
cons:
Not every department is like mine. I know two people who work for two different departments. Person A is micromanaged horribly. He takes heat for clocking in 5 minutes early to clocking out late or too early, or not going on his assigned lunch breaks for the assigned period of time, or showing up at a meeting 2 minutes early, "It's 758am, I told you the meeting wasn't until 8am." That is exactly what happened to him one time. It's not his fault, it's just his supervisor has control issues who doesn't trust any body and is anal retentive about everything. I have occasionally had to work with the supervisor of Person B and it's similar to what Person A goes through. This particular supervisor is one of those people who brings her emotions to the job, "I don't like this. I don't want to do it. Do it this way, not that way because that's the way I like it. What are you doing? Let me watch you and call you and check up on you for everything that I asked you to do." It's so much it becomes overbearing and her trust issues start to show. You get treated as if you're some dishonest child that can't be left alone to do a job. 

Also, salaries are too low, like most people have complained. I would need a $7,000 raise just to be on par with what the Virginia average is for someone with my kind of degree and in my position.

job_title: Clinical Research Recruiter in Chesapeake, VA
pros: My department has a very laid back feel. I enjoy my coworkers and am left alone to do my job, without micromanagement.
cons: Unless you request sick or vacation time two weeks in advance you get an occurrence. 5 occurrences in a 6 month period gets you a verbal warning, then a written one, then probation. It is very hard to know you are going to be sick two weeks ahead of time.

pros: The company has multiple building so you will never meet everyone but you will communicate through email alot! I worked in research and I loved it, the company has great benefits and add-ons. You can definitely see yourself staying with this company for the long haul.
cons: Only downside is that the dean does not really focus to much on research which is why that sector is decreasing. Its all about the clinical departments. Also, faculty and higher-ups are the only workers who get great raises and the perks.

pros: Great place to work and great work environment.  They continue to improve and grow the campus and programs.  I think there is a lot of potential at EVMS over the year to come.
cons: Outside of medically-based positions, fewer opportunities for advancement.  Due to pay scales, no raises outside of promotions.
